unnormalised: Okay, so, there's this buzz going around about LaTeX, right? Apparently, even my cousin Rohan, who thinks calculus is some fancy coffee drink, is suddenly all about it. It started when he saw someone on Insta posting a perfectly typeset equation – you know, the kind that looks like it belongs in a textbook, not scribbled on the back of a napkin. Turns out, LaTeX is the secret sauce.

It started when he saw someone on I-N-S-T-A posting a perfectly typeset equation – you know, the kind that looks like it belongs in a textbook, not scribbled on the back of a napkin. Turns out, L-A-Tex is the secret sauce.

unnormalised: For those of us who haven't stumbled down the rabbit hole yet, LaTeX (pronounced "Lay-tech" or "Lah-tech," depending on who you ask – the debate is real, folks!) is basically a typesetting system. Forget dragging and dropping in MS Word; with LaTeX, you're coding the document's structure using markup tags. Think HTML, but for documents that need to look professionally gorgeous, especially when dealing with complicated math.

unnormalised: Now, why the sudden craze? Well, apparently, it's not just about looking pretty. According to some folks on Reddit, LaTeX forces you to think about the logical structure of your document *before* you worry about the aesthetics. Makes sense, no? Like, instead of fiddling with fonts and spacing for 3 hrs, you're actually focusing on the content. Smart move.
